Scheme 1 Reaction model of Co/ZrO2 and CoAl(1)/ZrO2 catalysts in the DRM. Scheme 1 Fig. 1 Elemental mapping of (A) calcined and (B) reduced CoAl(1)/ZrO2. The red, green, and blue colors correspond to Zr, Co and Al elements, respectively (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article). Fig. 1 Fig. 2 TPR profiles of calcined CoAl(x)/ZrO2 catalysts, (a) Al(1)/ZrO2, (b) x = 0, (c) 0.5, (d) 1.0, (e) 1.5, and (f) 2.0. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 TGA profiles of reduced (a,c) Co/ZrO2 and (b,d) CoAl(1)/ZrO2 catalysts under different gas conditions; (A) CO2/He, and (B) CH4/He or CH4/CO2/Ar. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 (A) CH4 and (B) CO2 conversions using CoAl(x)/ZrO2 reforming catalysts with different Al content. Reaction conditions: 0.05 g catalyst, T = 850 °C, SV = 60,000 cm3/gcat h, and CH4/CO2/N2 (vol.%) = 40/40/20. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Conversion profiles of (A) Co/ZrO2 and (B) CoAl(1)/ZrO2 catalyst during the sequential DRM and CO2 treatment. Reaction conditions: 0.05 g catalyst, T = 850 °C, SV = 60,000 cm3/gcat h, and CH4/CO2/N2 (vol.%) = 40/40/20, CO2/N2 = 40/60, and H2/Ar = 5/95. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Stability test for the DRM over the CoAl(1)/ZrO2 catalyst. Reaction conditions: 0.05 g catalyst, T = 850 °C, SV = 60,000 cm3/gcat h, and CH4/CO2/N2 (vol.%) = 40/40/20. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 XP spectra of the (A) Co/ZrO2, (B) CoAl(1)/ZrO2 and (C) Al spectra of CoAl(1)/ZrO2 catalyst. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 (A) TGA and (B) DTG profiles of used CoAl(x)/ZrO2 catalysts in an air flow; (a) x = 0, (b and b’) 1.0, and (c) 2.0. (b′) was conducted under a 10%CO2/He flow. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 TPO profiles of used CoAl(x)/ZrO2 catalysts; (a) x = 0, (b) 0.5, (c) 1.0, (d) 1.5, and (c) 2.0. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 TEM images of used CoAl(x)/ZrO2 catalysts; (a) x = 0, (b) EDX result of (a), (c) 1.0, and (d) 2.0. Graphical abstract Addition of an appropriate amount of Al to the Co/ZrO2 catalyst enhance the oxidation resistance of active cobalt species during the dry reforming of methane. The dry reforming of methane (DRM) was performed on the Al-promoted CoAl(x)/ZrO2 catalysts (x = 0 − 2 wt.%). The addition of a small amount of Al led to an apparent promotional effect on the catalytic activity and stability of the Co-based catalyst. The largest promotional effect was observed for the Co/ZrO2 catalyst with 1 wt.% of Al loading. Although the Co/ZrO2 catalyst exhibited considerable catalytic activity, it was rapidly deactivated during the DRM, while the Al-promoted catalysts exhibited a stable catalytic activity. The addition of appropriate amount of Al species might be caused the strong interaction with the cobalt species at either the ZrO2 surface or near the interfacial region. Thus, the Al promoter led to the enhancement of the catalytic performance of Co/ZrO2 catalyst system by acting as a structural stabilizer. Keywords Dry reforming of methane Cobalt catalyst Al2O3 promoter Strong interaction Structural stabilizer 1 Introduction Carbon dioxide (CO2) is one of the most potent greenhouse gases responsible for the rising global temperature and drastic climate change. Other atmospheric greenhouse gases include methane (CH4), which has been found to be 21 times more potent than CO2 [1]. In order to address the growing concern over global climate change, a lot of effort has been made to reduce the amounts of the two aforementioned greenhouse gases and utilize them to as valuable feedstock. Dry reforming of CH4 with CO2 (DRM, CH4 + CO2 → 2CO + 2H2, ΔH°298 = +247 kJ/mol) has attracted considerable attention as a promising means of reducing and converting CH4 and CO2 into the valuable synthesis gas (syngas, CO + H2) and clean H2 [2–5]. Subsequent purification and separation process for syngas are not required when it is used as feedstock for the synthesis of other chemicals and fuels [2–9]. However, the syngas prepared in this manner has a H2/CO ratio lower than 1 because of the simultaneous occurrence of the reverse-water gas shift reaction (RWGS, CO2 + H2 ↔ H2O + CO, ΔH°298 = −41.1 kJ/mol). The RWGS reaction has a negative effect on the production of H2 because the product of the DRM (i.e., H2) reacts with the reactant CO2 to form CO and H2O. In addition, the product H2O may adsorb on the catalyst surface during the DRM, and together with high temperature, adversely affect the catalytic performance. Most group 8–10 metals have been widely investigated as reforming catalysts because of their excellent ability to break CH bonds [2–5] Although the supported noble metal catalysts, e.g., Pt [3], Rh [10], Ru [11], and Ir [12,13], show good catalytic performance and are more resistant to carbon deposition during the DRM, their high cost and limited availability hinder their practical application [2–5]. Although Ni-based catalysts are an attractive alternative to noble metal catalysts for the DRM because of their high catalytic activity, abundance, and low cost [13–18], they are rapidly deactivated under harsh reaction conditions. This is primarily because of the coke deposition that resulted from their high affinity to carbon atoms and sintering of active Ni species [5]. Coke deposition takes place mainly by methane cracking (CH4 ↔ C + 2H2, ΔH°298 = +75 kJ/mol) and CO disproportionation (2CO ↔ C + CO2, ΔH°298 = −172 kJ/mol). In contrast, Co-based catalysts can be considered as appropriate active metals with sufficient activity for the DRM [19,20]. These catalysts have a high resistance to carbon deposition during the DRM and can control the rate of carbon formation by oxidizing the surface carbon [21–23]. However, Co-based catalysts are susceptible to deactivation resulting from the oxidation of metallic Co and the formation of inactive spinel structures, which lead to a reduction in the number of active sites [24–26]. Addition of trace amounts of noble metals such as Pt or Ru to Co could effectively suppress the oxidation of metallic Co, and these catalysts showed stable catalytic performance [27]. As another strategy for preventing metal oxidation, base metal oxides such as those of Ni [28–30 and Zn [31,32] were employed to control the oxidation of metallic Co and the carbon deposition on the catalyst. Takanabe et al. [33] reported that a significant amount of carbon was deposited on the monometallic Ni/TiO2 catalyst at lower temperatures, while the pure Co/TiO2 catalyst was oxidized by CO2 during the DRM reaction. On the other hand, the combined Ni-Co catalyst exhibited both, a high catalytic activity and resistance to carbon deposition and metal oxidation, during the DRM. Although it has not been extensively studied for the DRM, Zn oxide can also be a good promoter for controlling the oxidation of the active Co [32]. Furthermore, a choice of suitable support can greatly influence the catalytic activity in the DRM. Ruckenstein et al. [34] found that the Co/MgO catalyst exhibited a high and stable catalytic activity in the DRM as it was able to avoid the sintering and oxidation resulting from the formation of a solid solution of CoO and MgO. The bimetallic Co-Ni supported on MgO was also found to be a promising catalyst for the DRM. In this case, a Co-Ni-MgO solid solution was formed during the reduction step because of the similar ionic radii of the metals [35,36]. As Co has a strong affinity for oxygen, the formation of a Ni-Co alloy is a reliable approach towards adjusting the affinity of C and O atoms of the catalyst. In our previous work, we found that a Co catalyst supported on phosphorus-modified Al2O3 exhibited a more stable catalytic activity than Co/Al2O3 in the DRM. The enhanced catalytic stability was attributed to the partial formation of an AlPO4 phase on the surface [37]. Al2O3 has also been used a good catalyst support and as a promoter because of its high mechanical strength and low cost. It was found that the addition of a small amount of Al2O3 to Co/SiO2 led to a significantly improved catalytic performance in the Fischer-Tropsch reaction because of the enhanced dispersion of Co and the increase in the surface area of metallic Co [38]. Pei et al. [39] also reported that the addition of appropriate amounts of Al2O3 led to the formation of Co2C on the surface of the Co/AC catalyst and resulted in an increase in the total alcohol fraction in the liquid products. Recently, Zhang et al. [40] reported that the Ni/AlSBA-15 catalyst possessed better hydrothermal stability than the Ni/SBA-15 catalyst in the dry and steam reforming of CH4. However, to the best of our knowledge, detailed studies of the promotional effect of Al on Co-based reforming catalysts have not been conducted. In this study, with the aim of improving catalytic performance and stability of the Co/ZrO2 catalyst in the DRM, a small amount of Al (0–2 wt.%) was added to these catalysts as a promoter by using the impregnation method. The Co/ZrO2 and Al-promoted Co/ZrO2 catalysts were characterized using various analytical tools and then applied for the DRM. The effect of the Al promoter on the catalytic performance has also been discussed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of the catalysts All chemicals used in this study were of analytical grade and were used without any further purification. The ZrO2 support was synthesized by simple precipitation method using an aqueous solution of ZrOCl2·8H2O (Junsei, 90%). The pH of the Zr solution was adjusted to 9.5 using NH4OH (Samchun, 28 vol.%) and aged at 80 °C for 1 h. The precipitating solution was filtered, washed several times with deionized-water, and dried overnight at 100 °C. The dried Zr hydroxide was calcined at 800 °C for 6 h in static air and used for preparing the Co-based catalysts. The Al-promoted Co/ZrO2 catalysts with varying Al content (0–2 wt.%) were prepared by the co-impregnation method using an aqueous solution of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (Samchun, 98%) and Al(NO3)2·9H2O (Samchun, 97%). The mixed solution was aged for 2 h at 25 °C, and the excess water was removed using a rotary evaporator (BUCHI R–210) at 60 °C. The resulting samples were dried at 100 °C for 12 h and subsequently calcined at 400 °C for 6 h in a muffle furnace in static air. The Co loading was fixed at 5 wt.% and the catalysts were designated as Co(x)Al/ZrO2, where x (x = 0, 0.5, 1.0, 1.5, and 2.0) represents the weight percentage of Al. In addition, the CoRu/ZrO2 catalyst (Ru/Co = 0.05 M ratio), which showed good catalytic activity in the DRM, was prepared by the co-impregnation method as a reference catalyst [27]. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The bulk and crystalline structures of the catalysts were recorded by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) using a Rigaku Ultima IV diffractometer with Ni-filtered CuKα radiation (1.5418 Å) operating at 40 kV and 40 mA at a scan rate of 1.2°/min. Inductively-coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometery (ICP-AES) was performed on the Thermo Scientific iCAP 6500 instrument. Prior to the analysis, all samples were dissolved in aqua regia. The crystallinities of carbon on the catalysts were analyzed by Raman spectroscopy (Bruker FRA 106/S FT-Raman spectrometer) with a laser wavelength of 532 nm. Raman spectra were collected under ambient conditions. The chemical states of the Co species of Co/ZrO2 and CoAl(1)/ZrO2 catalyst were identified by XPS on an Axis Nova electron spectrometer (AlKα radiation; hλ = 1486.6 eV). The analyses were performed on the catalyst calcined at 400 °C, sample reduced at 850 °C, and after the DRM. The XPS data were calibrated using the binding energy of C1s (284.8 eV) as the standard. The surface areas and total pore volumes of the samples were determined from the adsorption and desorption isotherms at liquid nitrogen temperature of −196 °C with a volumetric method using the Micromeritics ASAP 2020 instrument. Prior to these measurements, 0.2 g of each catalyst was degassed under a flow of N2 at 150 °C for 4 h. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method was used to determine the surface areas at P/P0 values in the range of 0.05 to 0.20. The total pore volumes were measured at P/P0 = 0.995. The reduction properties of the catalysts were studied by temperature-programmed reduction of H2 (H2–TPR) with the Micromeritics ASAP 2920 instrument. Each catalyst sample (0.05 g) was pretreated at 300 °C for 1 h under Ar flow (30 cm3/min) and then cooled to room temperature. The sample was subsequently reduced by increasing the temperature to 900 °C at a ramp rate of 10 °C/min in a stream of 10% H2/Ar. Temperature-programmed oxidation (TPO) analysis was performed using the same instrument with H2–TPR measurements. The catalyst sample (0.02 g) after 20 h reaction was loaded on U-shape quartz reactor, and TPO analysis was carried out by increasing the temperature to 900 °C at a ramp rate of 10 °C/min under 5% O2/Ar. The dispersions of Co and the Co-metallic surface areas were obtained from temperature-programmed desorption of H2 (H2-TPD) using the Micromeritics ASAP 2920C instrument. The samples were reduced at 850 °C for 1 h under 10%H2/Ar flow (30 cm3/min) and then cooled to 100 °C. The 10%H2/Ar gas was adsorbed the catalyst bed for 1 h at same temperature, and subsequently purged under Ar flow (30 cm3/min) to remove the physisorbed H2. Desorption behavior of H2 was examined by increasing the temperature to 900 °C at a ramp rate of 10 °C/min under an Ar stream. Cobalt dispersion was calculated as the ratio between the number of surface active Co sites to the total number of Co moles in the catalyst. The metal surface area and metal dispersion were calculated using following equations; M e t a l s u r f a c e a r e a ( m 2 / g C o ) = V m × N a S f × S d M e t a l d i s p e r s i o n ( % ) = V m × A w × 10 4 W % × S f where V m is the number of surface active Co species (μmol/gcat), N a is the Avogadro number (6.023 × 1023), S f is the stoichiometric factor of the reaction (H/Coatom = 1), S d is the metal surface density (0.146 × 1020 atoms/m2), A w is the metal atomic weight, and W% is the metal percentage in the sample. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on a TA Instruments SDT 2960 analyzer. The used samples were heated from 30 to 900 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min under air. To examine the degree of oxidation by CO2 and the rate of carbon deposition by CH4 decomposition on the Co/ZrO2 and CoAl(1)/ZrO2 catalysts, TGA analyses were carried out on a Mettler Toledo TGA/DSC 1. Prior to the analysis, all samples were reduced at 850 °C for 1 h under 10%H2/He flow (30 cm3/min) and afterwards, the gas mixtures of either 10%CH4/He, 5%CO2/He, or 40%CH4/40%CO2/Ar were introduced over the sample bed. To examine the type of carbon formed during the DRM, transmission electron micrographs (TEM) of the used catalysts were obtained on a Jeol JEM-2000FXII electron microscope operated at 200 kV and equipped with a Schottky-type field-emission gun (FEG) and EDXJEOL JED-2300D instrument. 2.3 Dry reforming of methane (DRM) The DRM was carried out in a fixed bed continuous-flow reactor at atmospheric pressure. The catalyst sample (0.05 g, 50–70 mesh) was loaded into a quartz reactor and pretreated at 750 °C for 1 h under 5% H2/Ar flow prior to the reaction. A mixture of CH4 (20 cm3/min) and CO2 (20 cm3/min) diluted with N2 (10 cm3/min) was introduced through the catalyst bed. The nitrogen was used as the internal standard. The gas products were separated using a packed column (Carboxen 1000) and analyzed using an on-line gas chromatograph (GC, Donam DC 6200 series) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector. Turnover frequency (TOF) of CH4 was calculated by dividing the number of moles of CH4 reacted per unit time by the number of moles of H2 uptake on the catalyst for the same mass of the catalyst. The conversions of CH4 and CO2, the H2/CO ratio, and the deactivation rate were calculated using following equations. C H 4 c o n v e r s i o n % = [ C H 4 ] i n - [ C H 4 ] o u t [ C H 4 ] i n × 100 C O 2 c o n v e r s i o n % = [ C O 2 ] i n - [ C O 2 ] o u t [ C O 2 ] i n × 100 S e l e c t i v i t y t o H 2 % = [ H 2 ] o u t 2 × ( [ C H 4 ] i n - [ C H 4 ] o u t ) × 100 S e l e c t i v i t y t o C O % = C O o u t { ( [ C H 4 ] i n - [ C H 4 ] o u t ) + ( [ C O 2 ] i n - [ C O 2 ] o u t ) } × 100 H 2 / C O = [ H 2 ] o u t [ C O ] o u t D e a c t i v a t i o n r a t e % = X i 1 h - X i 20 h X i 1 h × 100 , i = C H 4 o r C O 2 T O F ( s - 1 ) = C o n v e r t e d m o l e n u m b e r o f C H 4 C o a t o m n u m b e r a t s u r f a c e To examine the oxidation of the active Co species by CO2 during the DRM, repetitive tests of the DRM and CO2 treatment were conducted on the Co/ZrO2 and CoAl(1)/ZrO2 catalysts at 850 °C. The DRM was tested under the same reaction conditions for 2 h and 40%CO2/N2 was introduced into the catalyst bed for 20 min in the CO2 treatment step (20 cm3/min). The outlet gases were analyzed using the same apparatus as described above. To study the role of Al on the activation of CH4 or CO2, the DRM was performed under the same conditions as described above. The m/z = 2 (·H2), 15 (·CH3), 28 (·CO), and 44 (·CO2) signals were detected on a mass spectrometer (HIDEN analytical HPR20). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the catalysts The XRD patterns of the calcined CoAl(x)/ZrO2 catalysts are shown in Fig. S1(A). All CoAl(x)/ZrO2 catalysts displayed the characteristic peaks of the monoclinic ZrO2 phase (#01-070-8739) [41]. The characteristic peaks of Co3O4 can be detected at 2θ = 31.3, 36.9, 38.6, 44.8, 55.7, 59.5 and 65.2°, but all peaks except for peak at 2θ = 36.9° were difficult to distinguish due to overlap with the peaks of ZrO2 support (#42-1467) [37]. No characteristic peaks of Al2O3 could be detected, either due to the presence of only a small amount of Al species or because the Al peak was overlapped with other peaks. The textural properties of the calcined CoAl(x)/ZrO2 catalysts are listed in Table 1 . The surface area of the ZrO2 support prepared by the simple precipitation method was ∼10 m2/g as a result of the high temperature calcination. The BET surface areas, and pore volumes of the CoAl(x)/ZrO2 catalysts increased progressively as the Al loading increased. The BET surface areas of the Co/ZrO2, CoAl(1)/ZrO2, and CoAl(2)/ZrO2 catalysts were determined to be 9.1, 13.2 and 16.0 m2/g, respectively. This trend may be explained by the formation of Al2O3 on the ZrO2 surface during the impregnation and successive calcination processes. The Al and Co contents of the CoAl(x)/ZrO2 catalysts were determined by ICP analysis and exhibited similar values as compared with the nominal ones, e.g., 0.9 wt.% of Al and 4.8 wt.% of Co comprised the CoAl(1)/ZrO2 catalyst, indicating that the catalysts used in this study were successfully prepared (Table 1). The dispersion of the impregnated Co and Al species on the ZrO2 support was confirmed by elemental mapping analysis (Fig. 1 ). While the Al species were dispersed on the surface or at the interface of ZrO2, the Co metal particles were observed to be either well-dispersed or aggregated on the ZrO2 support. The formation of aggregates could be explained by the use of the simple impregnation method which could not control the size of the metal particles. It is generally recognized that carbon deposition is closely related to the metal particle size; metal particles with a small size can suppress metal sintering and coking. Numerous studies have attempted to establish stable reforming catalysts with coke-resistance by controlling the metal particle size [42]. The H2-TPR profiles of the calcined CoAl(x)/ZrO2 catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 . The Al(1)/ZrO2 sample did not show any reduction peak in the temperature range used for the TPR experiment. On the other hand, the Co-oxide in all the CoAl(x)/ZrO2 catalysts were reduced at given analysis conditions. The Al-unpromoted Co/ZrO2 catalyst exhibited two reduction peaks in the temperature ranges of 220–300 °C (peak α) and 300–450 °C (peak β). The α and β peaks were associated with the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO and the subsequently reduction of CoO to metallic Co, respectively [35,37]. For the Al-promoted Co catalysts, two main peaks and another broad peak, were observed from 450 to 630 °C. The two peaks related to the reduction of cobalt oxide were shifted to a higher temperature region as compared to those of the Co/ZrO2 catalyst when the Al loading reached up to 1 wt.%. On the other hand, the reduction peaks of catalysts loaded with more than 1 wt.% of Al were shifted to a lower temperature as compared to those of the CoAl(1)/ZrO2 catalyst. This result suggested that the interactions between the Co species and the support were strengthened by addition of Al to the catalyst, and the 1 wt.% of Al-promoted Co catalyst had the strongest interaction with ZrO2 support among the all samples. The shoulder peak observed at 450–630 °C was attributed to the reduction of cobalt species with different particle sizes [38] and this peak also shifted to higher temperatures with the increasing Al load. To summarize, the addition of Al into the Co/ZrO2 catalyst system led to a strong interaction between the cobalt species and the added Al and created a new interfacial region that had a positive effect on the physicochemical properties of the catalysts. A small and broad peak observed at 830 °C could be attributed to the reduction of the CoOx-Al2O3 phase formed on the ZrO2 surface [43]. The dispersion of cobalt in the CoAl(x)/ZrO2 catalysts was studied by H2-TPD analysis and the metallic surface area and dispersion of cobalt thus determined are given in Table 2 . All the CoAl(x)/ZrO2 catalysts revealed similar H2 desorption patterns; thus, the H2-TPD profile for CoAl(1)/ZrO2 catalyst is shown in Fig. S2. Several desorption peaks were observed and can be classified three different sites. The low temperature peak (<200 °C) is attributed to weakly-bounded hydrogen on the catalyst. The medium temperature peak (200–600 °C) is associated with the chemisorbed hydrogen on the metal surface and the small peak at high temperature (>600 °C) is ascribed to desorption of spillover hydrogen from the surface [44]. The number of surface active Co species was obtained by integrating the low temperature peak in H2-TPD profiles. It was found that the metal dispersion and surface area of cobalt increased with the Al loading until a load of 1 wt.% had been introduced and decreased with higher loadings. The CoAl(1)/ZrO2 catalyst possessed the highest surface area of 1.03 m2/g and the Co/ZrO2 catalyst had the lowest value of 0.68 m2/g. This result implied that the amount of exposed cobalt species increased with increasing Al loading in the reduced CoAl(x)/ZrO2 catalysts. In addition, all Al-promoted catalysts had a larger cobalt dispersion than the Co/ZrO2 catalyst. In case of the Al-promoted Co/ZrO2 catalysts, the addition of Al species into the Co/ZrO2 catalyst might have formed active interfaces between the cobalt species and ZrO2 support, at which the H2 or reactants were easily accessible. To examine the bulk oxidation of the Co species by CO2, TGA was conducted on the Co/ZrO2 and CoAl(1)/ZrO2 catalysts under CO2 flows (Fig. 3 (A)). Prior to the analysis, both catalysts were reduced at 850 °C under 10%H2/He flows; the change in the weight of the samples was attributed to the two–step reduction of Co3O4 (Fig. S3). Although the weight increase could be related to the adsorption of CO2 species during the TGA measurement under CO2 flow, it was not detected any desorption peak of CO2 in CO2-TPD analysis for reduced catalyst (Fig. S4). Thus, we assumed that the increase in weight of the samples corresponded to the oxidation of metallic species by surfacial oxygen species derived from CO2 dissociation. As shown in Fig. 3, the weight of both samples increased gradually up to 60 min due to the oxidation of Co when the mixture of CO2/He was introduced to the catalyst bed. The weight of both samples did not change after being exposed to CO2 for 60 min. In addition, regardless of the absence or presence of the Al component, both of these catalysts were oxidized in TGA. To further study the changes in the carbon deposition and oxidation degree, TGA was carried out under CH4/He (CH4 decomposition) or CH4/CO2/Ar flows (Fig. 3(B)). The weights of both catalysts increased with the introduction of the mixture of CH4/He to the catalyst bed, indicating that the carbon species originating from the dissociation of CH4 was deposited on the surficial Co species. The weight of the Co/ZrO2 catalyst increased significantly until the reaction time of 15 min and subsequently increased slowly. On the other hand, the weight of the CoAl(1)/ZrO2 catalyst increased gradually during the TGA under CH4/He flows. The carbon deposition rate of the Co/ZrO2 catalyst (922 ⎧mol C/mmol Co) was faster than that of the CoAl(1)/ZrO2 catalyst (411 μmol C/mmol Co), indicating that the Co/ZrO2 catalyst can better facilitate CH4 dissociation than CoAl(1)/ZrO2 catalyst. Under reactant flow, the weights of both samples gradually increased with time. The co-feeding of CO2 with CH4 led to a small and slow increase in the weights of both samples as compared to the TGA results of CH4 decomposition. This indicated that the carbon species deposited on the catalyst could be oxidized by CO2. The CoAl(1)/ZrO2 catalyst revealed low carbon deposition of 73 ⎧mol C/mmol Co (54 ⎧mol O/mmol), whereas the Co/ZrO2 catalyst possessed 365 ⎧mol/mmol Co of carbon (273 ⎧mol O/mmol). The difference in the amount of deposited carbon between only CH4 flows and CH4/CO2 co-flows over Co/ZrO2 and CoAl(1)/ZrO2 catalysts was 60.4% and 82.2%, respectively. It has been reported that the dissociation of CH4 is a rate determining step for the DRM [4]. Methane is decomposed into various CHx species on the active metal sites and the final form of Cads (carbon adsorbed on the metal surface) remains on the metallic sites [4,45,46]. The weight of the Co/ZrO2 catalyst was gradually increased during TGA under CH4/CO2 flows, although it was not too large. The increasing weight was associated with the carbon deposition resulting from CH4 activation, or the metallic Co oxidation by surface oxygen species originated from the CO2 dissociation. Although it was difficult to determine the relative rate of between both causes, we can speculate the trend of weight change from the TGA profiles. Methane was dissociated to form H2 and active carbon species on metallic Co, and the adsorbed CO2 on the ZrO2 surface was activated to form CO and surface oxygen species. The deposited carbon species reacted with the surface oxygen species to form CO. As CO2 is mildly acidic, the adsorption of CO2 would be more facile on a basic support rather than an acidic support. The carbon species were oxidized to CO by the active surface oxygen species derived from the activation of CO2 and excess oxygen species formed by the basic ZrO2 support led to further oxidation of metallic Co to cobalt oxide. Further oxidation of Co species because of its oxygen affinity resulted in the deactivation of the Co/ZrO2 catalyst over time. On the other hand, the CoAl(1)/ZrO2 catalyst revealed a slow increase in weight during the analysis resulted from the balance between carbon deposition, and the oxidation of carbon or Co by surface oxygen species on the catalyst surface. 3.2 Catalytic performance in DRM The performance of the synthesized catalysts for the DRM was studied at 850 °C for 20 h using a molar ratio of 40%CH4/40%CO2/20%N2. Fig. 4 shows the conversions of CH4 and CO2 after 1 h and 20 h, and the corresponding deactivation rates. For all catalysts, CO2 conversion was slightly higher than CH4 conversion because of the RWGS reaction accompanying the DRM. The Al-unpromoted Co/ZrO2 catalyst gave reasonable initial CH4 and CO2 conversions of ∼63% and 78%, respectively; however, these conversions gradually decreased with 20 h on stream (Fig. S5). The Co/ZrO2 catalyst exhibited the largest difference between the conversions achieved at 1 h and 20 h, indicating that this catalyst was quickly deactivated during the DRM. On the other hand, Al-promoted catalysts showed better catalytic activity and stability as compared to the Co/ZrO2 catalysts, regardless of the Al content. The conversions of CH4 and CO2 increased as the Al content in the catalyst was increased up to 1 wt.%. A further increase in the Al content exerted an opposite effect. Initially, there was no substantial differences in the conversions achieved with the Al-promoted catalysts. However, the conversions after 20 h reaction displayed large variations. Of all the tested catalysts, the CoAl(1)/ZrO2 catalyst displayed the highest CH4 and CO2 conversions of 67.6% and 84.8% after 20 h on stream, respectively. When the Al content was increased to 1 wt.%, the deactivation rate of CH4 and CO2 decreased significantly, although a further increase in the Al content increased the deactivation rate of both reactants. Overall, however, the deactivation rates of all CoAl(x)/ZrO2 catalysts were lower than that of the unmodified Co/ZrO2 catalyst. The H2/CO ratios in the case of all CoAl(x)/ZrO2 samples, with the exception of the Co/ZrO2 catalyst, were observed to be around 0.8 (Fig. S5(C)). The selectivity to H2 and CO2 displayed in Table S1. After 1 h reaction, the Al-promoted Co/ZrO2 catalysts showed ∼91% and 95% selectivity for H2 and CO, respectively. Both values were slightly decreased in 85% and 94% due to the decrease in the catalytic activity. On the other hand, the Co/ZrO2 catalyst displayed 83% and 129% selectivity to H2 and CO and decreased up to 30% for H2 selectivity. The selectivity to CO2 for all the catalysts was higher than that of H2 due to the RWGS during the DRM. The largest promotional effect was observed for the 1 wt.% Al-promoted Co/ZrO2 catalyst under the given reaction conditions. The CH4 and CO2 conversions of the CoRu/ZrO2 catalyst as a reference are shown in Fig. S5. Although the Ru-promoted catalyst displayed a good initial activity because of the presence of active Ru species, the DRM was suspended within 5 h on stream as a results of the reactor plugging from the large amount of formed carbon. As the CH4 molecules were easily decomposed on the active Co and Ru components, a large amount of carbon derived from the CH4 decomposition accumulated rapidly on the catalyst surface. Although the Al-promoted catalyst displayed a lower activity as compared to Ru-promoted catalyst, the Al additive can be considered as a good promoter because of its contribution to the enhancement of catalytic stability and advantages from an economic point of view. Although the Co-based catalysts showed a reasonable activity in the DRM, the active metallic cobalt atoms were prone to oxidation by CO2. Consequently, the catalytic activity decreased because of the loss of active sites or transformation of the inactive phase. To examine the effect of CO2, which is a mild oxidizing agent, on the catalytic activity, the repetitive experiments of DRM/CO2 treatment were conducted using the Co/ZrO2 and CoAl(1)/ZrO2 catalysts (Fig. 5 ). The DRM was carried out at 850 °C for 2 h and subsequently, CO2 was introduced into the catalyst bed for 20 min using a mixture of 40%CO2 and N2. This sequence of reactions was repeated three times. The Co/ZrO2 catalyst exhibited similar CH4 and CO2 conversions during the first 2 h of the DRM when compared with those attained after 20 h. After CO2 treatment for 20 min, the conversions in the second DRM were significantly lower than those achieved in the first reaction, and the reduction rate of both values were more accelerated. On repeating the DRM and CO2 treatment steps, the CH4 and CO2 conversions finally decreased to 10% and 23%, respectively, as a result of either partial or complete oxidation of metallic cobalt to the oxidized cobalt phases during the CO2 treatment. After repeating the tests three times, the Co/ZrO2 catalyst was treated for 20 min using a mixture of 5% H2/Ar to regenerate the active metallic cobalt species, and the DRM was conducted again. Although the conversion over the Co/ZrO2 catalyst was not recovered to the values of the first DRM run, both values were slightly increased during the reaction time. The CoAl(1)/ZrO2 catalyst also exhibited similar trend as compared to those of the Co/ZrO2 catalyst. By the repeating the reactions, however, the conversions of CH4 and CO2 of the CoAl(1)/ZrO2 catalyst decreased to ∼40% and 59%, respectively. During the repeating tests with DRM and CO2 treatment, the catalysts were exposed continuously in reductive and oxidative atmosphere. The surface of cobalt species will be reconstructed under the exposure in harsh conditions, and might be changed to difficult to reducible phase. Thus, it can be speculated that the catalytic performance was not recovered due to surface reconstruction despite the reduction treatment. The Al-promoted catalyst displayed more resistance towards CO2 treatment as compared to the Co/ZrO2 catalyst. The cobalt metal dispersion and surface area of the CoAl(x)/ZrO2 catalysts were well correlated with the initial CH4 and CO2 conversions (Table 2). However, the turnover frequency (TOF) of methane, determined by dividing the number of moles of CH4 consumed by the number of surficial Co atoms, was slightly decreased with increasing Al loading; the TOFs for the Co/ZrO2, CoAl(1)/ZrO2, and CoAl(2)/ZrO2 catalysts were revealed to be 0.652, 0.637, and 0.618 s−1, respectively (Table 2). This indicated that the active sites for CH4 activation was decreased with increasing the Al loadings on the Co/ZrO2 catalyst. The reaction rate of CH4 at different temperatures on Co/ZrO2 and CoAl(1)/ZrO2 catalyst was plotted as a function of 1/T (Fig. S6). The apparent activation energy can be estimated from the Arrhenius plot. The apparent activation energies on Co/ZrO2 and CoAl(1)/ZrO2 exhibited the 64.5 kJ/mol and 71.3 kJ/mol, respectively. The estimated apparent activation energy was quite lower compared to previously reported values of 96.4–98.1 kJ/mol for lanthania-supported cobalt catalyst [47]. The low activation energy of Co/ZrO2 catalyst can lead to a facile activation of CH4 compared to that of CoAl(1)/ZrO2 catalyst, and which is in good agreement with the results of CH4-TGA. To assess the stability of the prepared catalysts, the long-term test was performed with the CoAl(1)/ZrO2 catalyst. As discussed above, the Al-unpromoted Co/ZrO2 catalyst rapidly deactivated within 20 h on stream. The CH4 and CO2 conversions of CoAl(1)/ZrO2 catalyst, which showed the best catalytic activity among all the catalysts studied here (Fig. 6 ), slowly decreased up to 80 h on stream due to progressive carbon deposition. Subsequently, the CoAl(1)/ZrO2 catalyst exhibited stable CH4 and CO2 conversions until the duration of the reaction temperature reached to 200 h. Therefore, it was be concluded from the results of the stability test that the addition of Al to the Co-based catalyst effectively enhanced the catalytic performance in the DRM, and that the Al promoter was a good alternative to noble metals. 3.3 Characterization of spent catalysts To examine the structural changes in the CoAl(x)/ZrO2 catalysts after the DRM, XRD analysis was performed on samples after the reaction at 850 °C for 20 h (Fig. S1(B)). In the case of the used catalysts, the peaks of Co3O4 were completely disappeared and the characteristic peak for metallic cobalt was observed at 2θ = 44.1° (#15-0816). During the DRM, metallic cobalt could be oxidized by CO2 and the oxidized cobalt phase was transformed into the CoAl2O4 phase by reacting with Al2O3 [48]. However, it was difficult to identify the characteristic peak of CoAl2O4 at 2θ = 31.1° (#82-2243) because of its small intensity and overlapping peaks of the monoclinic ZrO2 phase. The XPS spectra of the Co 2p and Al 2p core-levels, obtained after the CoAl(x)/ZrO2 catalysts were calcined at 400 °C, reduced at 850 °C and used for DRM, are shown in Fig. 7 . Here, no remarkable changes were observed in the oxidation states of Co and Al among the Al-promoted Co/ZrO2 catalysts. Therefore, we compared the XP spectra of the Co/ZrO2 and CoAl(1)/ZrO2 catalysts. The Co 2p peaks of the calcined catalysts were observed at 795.6 eV (Co 2p1/2) and 780.3 eV (Co 2p3/2), while the primary spin-orbit binding energy (B.E.) values were separated by 15.3 eV, indicating that two types of Co species were present on the catalyst surface [49]. The Co3O4 displays a spinel structure because of the various oxidation state of cobalt, in which one-third of the cobalt species was located in tetrahedrally-coordinated sites [50]. The combination of the two oxidation states result in the asymmetric shape of the Co 2p3/2 peak. After reduction, a characteristic peak corresponding to metallic Co was observed at 778.6 eV on both catalysts. The peak intensity of both samples after reduction was decreased compared with that of calcined sample. It might be caused by diffusive processes of Co species towards the bulk upon the exposure in reducing atmosphere. The used samples also exhibited similar patterns to those of the calcined samples, indicating that the surface cobalt species were oxidized during the DRM. In addition, the small peak related to the CoOx-Al2O3 nanocrystals was observed at 781.7 eV with a broad satellite at ∼786.5 eV [51]. The peak intensity of Co/ZrO2 catalyst after the DRM was much larger than that of after exposed in different conditions because the Co species was diffused towards the surface by exposed between oxidizing and reducing conditions. On the other hand, the CoAl(1)/ZrO2 catalyst displayed lower peak intensity than that of Co/ZrO2 catalyst because the diffusion of Co species towards the catalyst surface was hindered by strong interaction with Co species and Al additive and by formed carbon species during the DRM. Fig. 7(C) shows the Al 2p spectra of the CoAl(1)/ZrO2 catalyst after calcination and the DRM. The Al 2p core-level of the calcined CoAl(1)/ZrO2 catalyst was observed at 74.1 eV, which corresponded to the Al3+ of Al2O3 [52]. In addition, the Al 2p core-level was almost constant to within 0.1 eV after the DRM. The Al 2p of highly dispersed CoAl2O4 on the surface of Al2O3 was very similar to that of Al2O3 [53]. The highly dispersed CoAl2O4 phase might be formed on the catalyst surface. In order to examine the type of carbon deposited during the DRM, TGA of the spent Co/ZrO2, CoAl(1)/ZrO2, and CoAl(2)/ZrO2 catalysts (Fig. 8 ) was performed. All catalysts exhibited several weight changes in the 50 to 900 °C temperature range. The weight increase between 200 and 400 °C was attributed to the oxidation of residual metallic cobalt. In case of the Co/ZrO2 catalyst, no weight change was observed during the oxidation of metallic cobalt, indicating that the amorphous or filamentous carbon were not deposited on the catalyst surface. In case of the Al-promoted Co/ZrO2 catalysts, the weight loss observed between ∼400 to 600 °C was associated with the oxidation of carbon deposited on the catalysts and no weight loss was observed above 600 °C. The TGA profile of the CoAl(1)/ZrO2 catalyst utilized under 5%CO2/He atmosphere is shown in Fig. 8. The weight of the catalyst gradually decreased in the temperature range from 500 °C to 900 °C and the reduction degree of weight was lower as compared with that of air condition. This result implied that the deposited carbon species could be oxidized in the presence of CO2, which acted as mild oxidant. DTG analysis showed that each constituent reacted at a different temperature (Fig. 8(B)). The CoAl(x)/ZrO2 catalyst exhibited a broad peak in the 300 to 650 °C temperature range, indicating that one type of carbon species were deposited on the catalyst, which is corresponded to the less-active filamentous carbon [53]. The filamentous carbon observed at temperatures higher than 450 °C was formed via a mechanism involving the diffusion of carbon through the metal particles, nucleation, and further growth on the top of metal particles [53]. In the case of the Co/ZrO2 catalyst, no distinct peak was observed in the entire analysis range. To further check the type of deposited carbon after the DRM, TPO analyses were conducted on the catalysts after 20 h DRM reaction (Fig. 9 ). The peak induced by carbon oxidation was observed in the 300–500 °C temperature range. Similarly to DTG results, the less-active carbon species were mainly detected for all samples. In addition, Raman analysis was performed on the CoAl(x)/ZrO2 catalysts after the DRM (Fig. S7). All catalysts with the exception of Co/ZrO2 exhibited two characteristic peaks at 1360 cm−1 (D band) and 1580 cm−1 (G band) belong to the amorphous- and graphite-type carbon, respectively [54]. The graphitization degree can be explained on the basis of ID/IG values of the carbon deposited during the DRM. The calculated ID/IG values were found to be 0.93, 0.81, 0.81, and 0.93 with increasing the Al loadings, respectively. The small ID/IG values indicated that the deposition of graphitic carbon is preferred than the non-crystalline carbon species [55]. Thus, TGA, TPO, and Raman spectroscopy results indicated that the deactivation of the CoAl(x)/ZrO2 catalysts was not entirely related to the amount of deposited carbon. However, as discussed above, the effect of carbon deposition on catalyst deactivation cannot be completely disregarded. Fig. 10 shows the TEM images of the used CoAl(x)/ZrO2 catalysts. The Al-promoted CoAl(x)/ZrO2 catalysts exhibited a typical filamentous carbon structure, while the metallic Co were observed in the middle or at the tips of the carbon filaments. The various sized Co particles, which was formed as a result of the metal sintering during the sample preparation and the DRM, were located on the filamentous carbon in the Al-promoted Co/ZrO2 catalysts. For the Co/ZrO2 catalyst, no filamentous-type carbon was observed. These observations for the used catalysts are in good agreement with the TGA and TPO results. The Co/ZrO2 catalyst was observed with the characteristic d-spacing of 0.26 nm corresponding to the (111) plane of CoO [56] and 0.25 nm and 0.21 nm associated with the (311) and (400) plane of Co3O4 [57], respectively, as a result of the oxidation by CO2. 3.4 Discussion In this study, although the Al component could not activate either CH4 or CO2 by itself during the DRM reaction, the addition of an appropriate amount of Al led to a significant improvement in the stability of the Co-based catalysts (Fig. 4). Obviously, the primary reason for deactivation of reforming catalysts is well known the coke deposition. Although there was an apparent change in the Co/ZrO2 catalyst weight related to carbon oxidation based on TGA and TPO results, this catalyst showed a gradual decrease in the conversions of CH4 and CO2. Therefore, it was speculated that there is another reason for the deactivation of the Co/ZrO2 catalyst i.e., the oxidation of the Co species. The Co-based reforming catalysts are typically susceptible to oxidation by CO2 during the DRM and are inevitably deactivated due to the loss of accessible active sites [37]. On the other hand, TGA of the CoAl(1)/ZrO2 catalyst revealed a significant decrease in the weight of the catalyst, but this seemed to be reasonable considering the catalytic activity of the CoAl(1)/ZrO2 catalyst. Based on the experimental results, a plausible reaction model for CoAl(x)/ZrO2 catalyst has been proposed in Scheme 1 . The activation and dissociation of CH4 takes place on the surface of Co particles to form H2 and carbon species. CO2 adsorbs on the ZrO2 support and dissociates into CO and surface oxygen species, which can then react with the neighboring carbon species originated from CH4 dissociation to produce CO. In the case of the Co/ZrO2 catalyst, the basic nature of ZrO2 promotes the adsorption of CO2 and the dissociated oxygen species, which does not react with the carbon species, remains on the surface of the catalyst. These surface oxygen species might lead to further oxidation of the active Co species. Therefore, the activity of the Co/ZrO2 catalyst decreases due to the partial oxidation of the active Co sites as well as the carbon deposition during the DRM. On the other hand, the addition of Al to the Co/ZrO2 catalyst can improve the oxidation resistance of the active Co species resulted from the strong interaction between Co species and Al promoter on the interfacial region between the Co and ZrO2 support. In addition, the Al-promoted ZrO2 is a weaker base than pristine ZrO2 due to the addition of acidic Al species. Consequently, the adsorption capacity of CO2 on Al(1)/ZrO2 is slightly lesser than that on ZrO2 (Fig. S2(B)) [58]. If the amount of surface oxygen species derived from CO2 dissociation is equal to those of the carbon species originated from the CH4 activation, the active Co species may not be further oxidized to inactive cobalt oxide. In addition, if the carbon removal rate and the supply of the oxygen species is imbalanced, the carbon could be deposited on the surface of the catalyst during the DRM. Practically, among the samples studied here, a large amount of carbon was deposited on the CoAl(1)/ZrO2 catalyst. Nevertheless, this catalyst showed better catalytic stability than that of the Co/ZrO2 catalyst. Based on the experimental results, we can speculate that the addition of an appropriate amount of Al species can suppress the oxidation of the active metallic Co species, by the strong interaction of CoOx-Al2O3 sites and kinetic control of the surface acid-base properties. 4 Conclusions In this study, Al-modified Co/ZrO2 catalysts (0–2 wt.% of Al) were prepared by a simple impregnation method, and the effect of Al addition on the performance of these catalysts in the DRM was studied. The addition of Al drastically improved the stability of the Co/ZrO2 catalysts in the DRM and the greatest effect was observed for the catalyst with 1 wt.% of Al. The addition of Al to the Co/ZrO2 catalyst led to an increase in the reduction temperature of the Co species due to enhanced interactions with the metal-support. The CoAl(1)/ZrO2 catalyst showed relatively high stability compared to that of Co/ZrO2 catalyst despite the large amount of carbon deposition, because the added Al species led to the formation of the strong interaction of CoOx on the ZrO2 surface. A small amount of Al modifier can play a role of structure stabilizer for Co-based catalyst and can be considered the promising promoter; however, this needs further study. coredata.dc:description: The dry reforming of methane (DRM) was performed on the Al-promoted CoAl(x)/ZrO2 catalysts (x = 0 − 2 wt.%). The addition of a small amount of Al led to an apparent promotional effect on the catalytic activity and stability of the Co-based catalyst. The largest promotional effect was observed for the Co/ZrO2 catalyst with 1 wt.% of Al loading. Although the Co/ZrO2 catalyst exhibited considerable catalytic activity, it was rapidly deactivated during the DRM, while the Al-promoted catalysts exhibited a stable catalytic activity. The addition of appropriate amount of Al species might be caused the strong interaction with the cobalt species at either the ZrO2 surface or near the interfacial region. Thus, the Al promoter led to the enhancement of the catalytic performance of Co/ZrO2 catalyst system by acting as a structural stabilizer.
coredata.dc:title: Promotional effect of Al addition on the Co/ZrO2 catalyst for dry reforming of CH4
